newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan says to stabilise markets over Deng's death.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan says to stabilise markets over Deng's death.

text.p: Taiwan's government spokesman Su Chi said on Thursday after a cabinet meeting that the government will continue to implement market-stabilisation measures following the death of China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping.

"As everyone knows the market-stabilisation ad-hoc taskforce has been functioning for a long time, different government agencies have been effectively exchanging information," Su told reporters at a news conference.
"The government will continue to implement market-stabilisation measures to handle any possible changes," Su said.
Su, briefing Thursday's cabinet meeting, said the government has prepared funds to support financial markets.
The stock market rebounded at mid-session after the government's assurance.
The central bank reported to the cabinet meeting that the bank saw no major impact on the foreign exchange market in the wake of Deng's death, Su said.
The bank reiterated its determination to stabilise the island's financial markets, Su said.
The cabinet also noted caution needed in investment in China, Su said.

"Although the mainland economic opening policies will not go backward, the economics ministry urges Taiwan businessmen to take political risks into consideration when considering medium- to long-term investments," Su quoted economic minister Wang Chih-kang as saying.
